International Restrictions:
South Sudan has reopened its land borders but all passengers should check restrictions in place from neighbouring countries. *Coronavirus (COVID-19) certificate: To enter South Sudan, you must have a certificate showing you are free from coronavirus, issued no more than 96 hours ahead of your journey, and endorsed by a reputable medical provider. You will also need to self-quarantine for 14 days on arrival. Public health requirements for humanitarian flights see here.

Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in South Sudan: An official government curfew is in force across South Sudan from 10pm to 6am. There are also some restrictions on public transport and inter-state movements. Passengers are required to wear face masks.
*Public places and services: Due to an increase in COVID-19 case numbers, new measures were introduced on 3 February 2021. Hotels, shops and restaurants are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Businesses which attract a crowd, including bars and nightclubs, are closed, as are schools and universities. Social gatherings, including sporting events, weddings and funerals, are banned.
